sect1.title: Normalization and Localization
sect1.para: Zend_Locale_Format is a internal subclass of Zend_Locale which provides normalization and localization for numbers and dates. All locale aware classes use this one for normalization and localization.

Therefor all functions need a proper locale for parsing.
Be aware
If no locale is given the standard locale will be taken for normalization and localization. This can lead to unpredicted behavior.

sect2.title: Number normalization
sect2.para: Numbers can be parsed with the getNumber() function. A normalized string of the number will be returned.

example.title: Number normalization
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$number = Zend_Locale_Format::getNumber('13.524,678', $locale);

// will return 13524.678
print $number;
?>

note.title: Unlimited numbers
note.para: getNumber() can normalize numbers with unlimited length. It is not related to integer or float limitations. So be aware using the output within calculations.

sect2.para: Also the precision can be truncated to a given length with getNumber(). A normalized string of the number will be returned. If no precision is given, the complete normalized number will be returned.

example.title: Number normalization with precision
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$number = Zend_Locale_Format::getNumber('13.524,678', 1, $locale);

// will return 13524.6
print $number;
?>

note.title: Be aware
note.para: getNumber() will truncate the input. The result will not be rounded. So 1.6 will not return 2 but 1 instead.

sect2.title: Number localization
sect2.para: toNumber() can localize any given number. This function will return a localized string of the given number.

example.title: Number localization
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$number = Zend_Locale_Format::toNumber(13547.36, $locale);

// will return 13.547,36
print $number;
?>

note.title: Unlimited length
note.para: toNumber() can localize numbers with unlimited length. It is not related to integer or float limitations.

sect2.para: The same way as within getNumber(), toNumber() handles precision. If no precision is given, the complete localized number will be returned.

example.title: Number localization with precision
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$number = Zend_Locale_Format::toNumber(13547.3678, 2, $locale);

// will return 13.547,36
print $number;
?>

note.title: Be aware
note.para: toNumber() will truncate the output. The result will not be rounded. So 1.6 will not return 2 but 1 instead.

sect2.title: Number testing
sect2.para: isNumber() checks if a given string is a number and returns true or false.

example.title: Number testing
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale();
if (Zend_Locale_Format::isNumber('13.445,36', 'de_AT') {
    print "Number";
} else {
    print "not a Number";
} 
?>

sect2.title: Float value normalization
sect2.para: Floating point values can be parsed with the getFloat() function. A floating point value will be returned.

example.title: Floating point value normalization
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$number = Zend_Locale_Format::getFloat('13.524,678', 2, $locale);

// will return 13524.67
print $number;
?>

sect2.title: Floating point value localization
sect2.para: toFloat() can localize floating point values. This function will return a localized string of the given number.

example.title: Floating point value localization
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$number = Zend_Locale_Format::toFloat(13547.3655, 1, $locale);

// will return 13.547,3
print $number;
?>

note.title: Be aware
note.para: toFloat() will truncate the output. The result will not be rounded. So 1.6 will not return 2 but 1 instead.

sect2.title: Floating point value testing
sect2.para: isFloat() checks if a given string is a floating point value and returns true or false.

example.title: Floating point value testing
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
if (Zend_Locale_Format::isFloat('13.445,36', $locale) {
    print "float";
} else {
    print "not a float";
} 
?>

sect2.title: Integer value normalization
sect2.para: Integer values can be parsed with the getInteger() function. A integer value will be returned.

$number = Zend_Locale_Format::getInteger('13.524,678', $locale);

// will return 13524
print $number;
?>

sect2.title: Integer point value localization
sect2.para: toInteger() can localize integer values. This function will return a localized string of the given number.

example.title: Integer value localization
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$number = Zend_Locale_Format::toInteger(13547.3655, $locale);

// will return 13.547
print $number;
?>

sect2.title: Integer value testing
sect2.para: isInteger() checks if a given string is a integer value and returns true or false.

example.title: Integer value testing

require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

if (Zend_Locale_Format::isInteger('13.445', $locale) {

?>

sect2.title: Normalize a date or time
sect2.para:
getDate() has the ability to parse a localized date. There will always be an array with the date values returned.
Return values
All return values are OPTIONAL. If only date is given all time values are supressed. If no time is given all date values are supressed.
Exception
If no date or time can be found within the given input, an exception will be thrown.

The following return values are possible :
Return values
Array key Returned value Minimum Maximum
day integer 1 31
month integer 1 12
year integer no limit no limit
hour integer 0 no limit
minute integer 0 59
second integer 0 59
But getDate() can now only handle given formats, it also knows local standard formats, so by using only the locale the used format can be automatically detected.

example.title: Normalizing a date by locale
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$date = Zend_Locale_Format::getDate('13.04.2006', false, $locale);

print_r ($date);
?>

sect2.para: Also a complete date can be parsed by only giving by giving a complete date as input.

example.title: Normalizing a date with time
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
$date = Zend_Locale_Format::getDate('13.04.2005 22:14:55', false, $locale);

print_r ($date);
?>

sect2.para: Of course also an unusalÂ´or userdefined format can be parsed.

The format can include the following signs :
Format definition
Format Letter Description
d or dd 1 or 2 digit day
M or MM 1 or 2 digit month
y or yy 1 or 2 digit year
yyyy 4 digit year
h 1 or 2 digit hour
m 1 or 2 digit minute
s 1 or 2 digit second

Examples for proper formats are
Example formats
Formats Input Output
dd.MM.yy 1.4.6 ['day'] => 1, ['month'] => 4, ['year'] => 6
dd.MM.yy 01.04.2006 ['day'] => 1, ['month'] => 4, ['year'] => 2006
yyyyMMdd 1.4.6 ['day'] => 6, ['month'] => 4, ['year'] => 1

note.title: Database date format
note.para: If you want to parse a database date value (f.e. MySql or MsSql) use Zend_Date's ISO_8601 format instead of getDate().

sect2.para: getDate() has an build in automatic correction for false inputs. It can detect false values and will fix them.

example.title: Correction for date normalizing
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$date = Zend_Locale_Format::getDate('41.10.20', 'ddMMyy');

// instead of 41 for the day, the 41 will be returned as year value
print_r ($date);
?>

sect2.title: Testing dates
sect2.para: Also dates can be tested the same way as numbers. isDate() checks if a given string contains a proper date and returns true or false.

example.title: Date testing
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale();
if (Zend_Locale_Format::isDate('13.Apr.2006', 'de_AT') {
    print "date";
} else {
    print "not a date";
} 
?>

sect2.title: Normalizing a time
sect2.para: Normaly a time will be returned with a date if the input contains both. But if the proper format is not known getTime() should be used. It detects the default time format from the given locale.

example.title: Normalize a unknown time
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
if (Zend_Locale_Format::getTime('13:44:42', $locale) {
    print "time";
} else {
    print "not a time";
} 
?>

sect2.title: Testing times
sect2.para: And last but not least times can be parsed like dates. isTime() checks if a given string contains a proper time and returns true or false.

example.title: Time testing
example.programlisting:
<?php
require_once 'Zend/Locale.php';
require_once 'Zend/Locale/Format.php';

$locale = new Zend_Locale('de_AT');
if (Zend_Locale_Format::isTime('13:44:42', $locale) {
    print "time";
} else {
    print "not a time";
} 
?>
